title: Configure a load balancer for UD/UCMDB port 443 (OpenShift)
content:
This topic describes how to configure an external load balancer (LB) for the UD/UCMDB.

After the UD/UCMDB installation, you need to get the actual node port of the frontend ingress, and then add traffic map rules to the load balancer. The port map points from port 443 to the actual node ports.

Expose port 443 on external LB (ClusterIP service)

Refer to the instructions in this section if your UD/UCMDB deployment uses ClusterIP service to expose the LB.  

After you complete the UD/UCMDB installation, you must update the OpenShift Router to add a route to allow external clients to access the UD/UCMDB on port 443.

Log in to the OpenShift web console

  1. Launch the OpenShift web console. For example, https://console-openshift-console.apps.myhost.example.com.
  2. Log in to the web console as kubeadmin and use the password that you specified during the OpenShift cluster installation. 

Create a route for port 443

Complete the following steps to create the route for port 443.

  1. Navigate to Networking > Routes, select <ucmdb_project> from the project list, and then click Create Route. 
  2. Provide the following information for the route:
    • Name: enter a descriptive name.
    • Hostname: enter the external access host name that you specified when running the install script. 
    • Service: select itom-ingress-controller-svc from the drop-down list.
    • Target Port: select 30443->8443 (TCP). 
    • Security:  select Secure route, and then select Passthrough in the TLS Termination field.
    • Other settings: keep their default value.
  3. Click Create.
  4. Log in to UD/UCMDB, for example, https://<external access host name>/cms,  as suite-admin and verify the configuration.
